title: Attributes for classifier feedback

author: Devi Parikh, School of Interactive Computing, College of Computing, Georgia Institute of Technology
chairman: Antonio Torralba, Center for Future Civic Media, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT
Stefan Carlsson, KTH - Royal Institute of Technology

So to get a little bit more concrete, what we're proposing is the following scenario, we have a learner which is a machine and we have a teacher who is human and the teacher wants to teach the machines several concepts, several visual concepts, Anna's teaching aid the teacher has access to an unlabeled pool of images that the teacher will label at each active learning nitration.
Now is learning it.
The machine has access to pre trained set of attribute predictors.
For a given query image that is actively chosen by the learner, the learner will convey its current belief, which is a predicted label for this image to the teacher.
And the teacher will provide 2 forms of feedback.
One is a label based feedback that either accepts or rejects the label that is predicted by the by the learner and the 2nd is if the label was rejected.
The teacher provides an attributes based reasoning as to why that label was rejected.
Both these forms of feedback are incorporated by the learner to updates to update its classifiers and the loop continues.
Note that these classifiers can be built in any feature space using any discriminative learning algorithm, just like you would in a traditional active learning sense.
So these classifiers are in no way tight to the attribute predictors that the learner has learned offline.
Now to tell you how exactly this works, I need to tell you three things.
The first is what are the attribute predictors that we use.
The second is how is the attributes based feedback incorporated in the classifiers and the third is what role the label based feedback plays.
So let's talk.
For the first one, that tribute predictors for attribute predictors, we use the notion of relative attributes that we that we introduced at ICC last year.
To recap, a relative attribute is modeled with.
The ranking function were given an image XI represented by its image features.
The strength of the attribute can be computed by a dot product between a weight vector and those image features.
These weight vectors are learned via learning to rank formulation using supervision of the form that tells you which images have a higher presence of the attribute than other images.

And once you've learned this relative attribute predictors, you can take any unlabeled pool of images, extract their features, evaluate the value of this relative attribute predictor on all the images, and sort them based on this predicted strength of the attribute.

Then how is this reasoning incorporated?
What it does is something is fairly straightforward.
The learner identifies the image that it had picked as a query from the data set, and it finds all images that are.
Even more open than the query image.
And since the query image is too open to be a forest.
It assumes that all these images that are even more open must not be for receiver.

Our contribution is the attributes based feedback.

In addition to that.

Now this statement can be extremely informative if this image being a forest implies that it cannot be anything else.
And this happens in a traditional classification scenario where each image can belong to one and only one class.

But the same feedback that says yes, this images of forest can have fairly less information if it means that in spite of this being a forest, an image can still be many other things, and this happens in an annotation scenario where each image can have multiple tags.

Was wrong for a given image, if it predicts this image to be a forest.

If the teacher manages to say that this is not a forest, it actually is a cost.
Now this is easy to do if it's a classification scenario with a few categories, and so the teacher can easily identify what the correct label is.

But this projection can be fairly weak if the only thing the teacher can say is that this is not a forest, but it can't tell the learner what it actually is, and this might happen in scenarios where you have many, many categories.
Perhaps some of them even require expert knowledge, and so the teacher cannot quite pinpoint what the true label of this image is.
It can only tell you that it's not a forest.
This can also happen in a simple binary classification setting where there are many more negative examples.
So just by saying that something is not a forest doesn't tell you much because there are many things that are not forests.
So in both these cases the label based feedback can be fairly weak.
So we experiment with four different scenarios where the strength of the label bag based feedback varies quite a bit and the details of that are in the paper.

The second data set is a scenes data set that also has eight categories and it has six different attributes like open, natural and so on.

Feedback exhaustively offline using Amazon Mechanical Turk.
